summary: hydrogel delivery of lysostaphin eliminates orthopedic implant infection by Staphylococcus aureus. hydrogel delivers antimicrobial enzyme lysostaphin to infected, implant-fixed, mouse femoral fractures. lysostaphin-delivering hydrogels outperform prophylactic antibiotic therapy. methylglucosylation of aromatic amino and phenolic moieties of drug-like biosynthons by combinatorial biosynthesis Linan Xie, Liwen Zhang, Chen Wang, Xiaojing Wang, Ya-ming Xu, Hefen Yu, Ping Wu, Shenglan Li, Lida Han, A. A. Leslie Gunatilaka, Xiaoyi Wei, Min Lin, István Mol Isolation of state-dependent monoclonal antibodies against the 12-transmembrane domain glucose transporter 4 using virus-like particles David F. Tucker, Jonathan T. Sullivan, Kimberly-Anne Mattia, Christine R. Fisher, Trevor Barnes, Manu N. Mabila, Rona Wilf, Chidananda Sulli, Meghan Pitts, Moniquetta Hall, Duncan Huston-Paterson, Xiaoxiang Deng, Edgar Davidson, Sharon H a mammalian formin mDia1 generates F-actin resistant to cofilin. helical rotation of formins may thus facilitate the formation of stabilized F-actin resistant to actin severing activities of cofilin. eukaryotes have the enzymatic machinery required to execute this modification. ligand 33 is key regulator of teleost fish barbel development. barbels are important sensory organs for food seeking of teleosts, reptiles, and amphibians. molecular basis of barbel development is unknown. chemokine gene ccl33 identified as key regulator of barbel development. study shows how hippopotami shape water chemistry and biodiversity patterns in a human-altered river. the influence of the hippopotamus was greatly altered such that its nutrient contributions promoted eutrophication and affected biodiversity. these results highlight the extent to which human modification of environmental systems may unexpectedly alter the impacts of ecologically influential species at multiple scales. a cohort of whole-genome sequences of 63 individuals from across its entire range opens avenues for incorporating population genomics into studies of speciation. the QTP is a natural laboratory for studying how selection drives adaptation, how environments influence reproductive isolation of populations of the species. PRDM1 silences stem cell-related genes and inhibits proliferation of human colon tumor organoids. this work provides support for a role of PRDM1 in regulating normal colon stem cell proliferation. IL-36/IL-36 receptor signaling is a central upstream driver of the IL-23/IL-22/antimicrobial peptide pathway during intestinal injury. findings provide new mechanistic insight into how the host commandeers proinflammatory cytokines for tissue repair. targetable BET proteins- and E2F1-dependent transcriptional program maintains the malignancy of glioblastoma. the immune system has been suggested to be critically linked to metabolic health, leading to the prospect of immune-directed therapies. the immune system has been suggested to be critically linked to metabolic health, leading to the prospect of immune-directed therapies. fetal preferred end sites were generally located in the nucleosome cores. maternal preferred end sites were located in the linker regions. analysis of size-tagged preferred ends could be used for measuring fetal DNA fraction and facilitating fetal trisomy 21 detection. udomonas aeruginosa transcriptome during human infection Daniel M. Cornforth, Justine L. Dees, Carolyn B. Ibberson, Holly K. Huse, Inger H. Mathiesen, Klaus Kirketerp-Mller, Randy D. Wolcott, Kendra P. Rumbaugh, Thomas Bjarnsholt, marvin whiteley microbiologists typically use laboratory systems to study the bacteria that infect humans. identification of aPN as a deltacoronavirus receptor emphasizes the remarkable preferential employment of cell surface host peptidases as receptors by coronaviruses. findings provide important insight into how receptor usage may fuel cross-host transmission between distantly related species. findings necessitate surveillance studies of deltacoronaviruses in thus far unappreciated potential reservoirs. n, fabrice Crivello, Nathalie Tzourio-Mazoyer, Simon E. Fisher, Paul M. Thompson, and Clyde Francks Left–right asymmetry is a key feature of the human brain's structure and function. it remains unclear which cortical regions are asymmetrical on average in the population and how biological factors such as age, sex, and genetic variation affect these asymmetries. this work supports the role for LRRK2 in immune-signaling and the role for the immune system in the pathogenesis and progression of PD. axon boutons of both input pathways are spatially organized according to their orientation preferences, forming orientation maps aligned to the V1 map. differences in human prefrontal cortex (PFC) compared with other primate species. disproportionately large amount of gray and white matter corresponding to PFC in humans compared with nonhuman primates. findings illuminate important allosteric interactions between topologically distinct domains of Orai1. salicylic acid-independent role of NPR1 is required for protection from proteotoxic stress in the plant endoplasmic reticulum Ya-Shiuan Lai, Luciana Renna, John Yarema, Cristina Ruberti, Sheng Yang He, and Federica Brandizzi. the biosynthetic ability of the endoplasmic reticulum is essential to eukaryotic life. the root-specific transcription factor MYB72 regulates the excretion of the coumarin scopoletin, an iron-mobilizing phenolic compound with selective antimicrobial activity that shapes the root-associated microbial community. our results suggest that probiotic root-associated microbes that activate the iron-deficiency response during colonization stimulate MYB72-dependent excretion of scopoletin. ventromedial prefrontal cortex encodes the expected value of a trial. ventromedial prefrontal cortex encodes the expected value of a trial. findings highlight how the brain computes and monitors value-based predictions during effortful goal-directed behavior. the cellular response to inflammation may be mechanistically and functionally regulated by temperature.
